III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules:
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12422 (3) (h) Foster care case record states a photograph taken at
least annually. Make sure a photograph of each child is taken annually.
• Rule 400.12418 (5) Development of service plans. This rule states an agency
shall involve the child’s parent or parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parent’s and foster parents to understand the plan and
to make sure this is occurring with each service plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: One
CAP submitted was in response to the 2023 interim inspection completed on
1/3/2024 and the CAP was approved on 1/22/2024. The agency was cited for 2
violations Policy FOM 722.08B and Policy FOM 722.08D. There were no repeat
violations during this reporting period.
A special investigation #2024SIC0001634 was initiated on 7/31/2024. The report
was completed on 11/8/2024, and the CAP is pending approval. The agency was
in non-compliance with Rule 400.12421, visitation and family time, in person
contact.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) discussed barriers that impeded the agency year. CA
reported that two foster care positions were vacant, and that staff turnover
continued to be an ongoing challenge for compliance. The CA reported that in
order to maintain caseload compliance and continuity of service delivery, it is
critical to have new hires available to fill vacancies. In situations where staff
departure is unexpected, it takes an extended amount of time to have a new staff
hired and trained for the vacant positions. The CA reports to improve outcomes for
their youth in care, Oakland County continues to partner with another private
agency to pilot the Kinship Connection program. The CA reported the Family
Engagement Specialists are responsible for relative search efforts at the onset of
the case for each child entering care. He said this has assisted staff in identifying
relatives for placement and establishing family supports. The CA reported this
initiative created an open door to economic concrete supports by imbedding
Family Resource Specialists within child welfare work units in Oakland County.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were interviewed via phone, and they reported their immediate
supervisors and coworkers are very supportive. The staff interviewed reported
they would not change anything about the agency at this time, they enjoy their
teams, the agency training and the overall environment.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has the space and equipment needed to perform job requirements.
The files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their
regular license.
